answers: 1527 Sack of Rome [do not accept or prompt on “French Sack of Rome”]
Holy Roman Empire [or HRE]
House of Gonzaga <NC, European History>
parts: Name this 1527 event that began after Francis I joined the League of Cognac (“KON-yak”). During this event, Caspar Roist led the Swiss Guard in its “last stand,” allowing an escape to the Castel Sant’Angelo.

The Sack of Rome was led by the unpaid troops of Charles V, the ruler of this diverse state led by the Hohenstaufen and Habsburg families. Voltaire quipped that it did not possess any of its three namesake qualities.
Among Charles V’s unpaid troops were a contingent of mercenaries led by Ludovico, the founder of this dynasty, which ruled Mantua for centuries afterward.

answers: Lenz’s law
Newton’s third law of motion [accept equivalents such as Newton 3; prompt on Newton’s laws]
retarded potential <WA, Physics>
parts: Name this law, which is basically the reason why there’s a negative sign in Faraday’s law of induction.
Lenz’s law is often thought of as analogous to this law of physics, which states that “for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.”

Maxwell’s equations in general get more complicated when you consider the finite speed of electromagnetic waves. Such situations are described with this sort of potential, which gives the potential at the current time generated by a time-variant source at an earlier time.

answers: Portland, Maine
Kansas
Election of 1880 <ML, US History>
parts: Name this city run in the 1850s by a man called the “Napoleon of Prohibition” for his short stature and zeal. That mayor of this city, Neal Dow, called in state militia to suppress backlash against a law he passed to ban alcohol.

An unrelated Dow, Charles Dow, was killed in this state’s city of Lawrence during a period named for its “Bleeding.” Carrie Nation carried out her first attack on a saloon in this state’s city of Kiowa (“KYE-oh-wuh”).

Neal Dow was convinced to run for president in this year’s election. He refused to withdraw despite fears that he would siphon votes from the winning candidate and allow a victory for Winfield Scott Hancock.

answers: Orpheus AND Eurydice
J. S. Bach [or Johann Sebastian Bach]
graphic novel [or comic book] <RK, Long Fiction>
parts: Name these two people whose story is interwoven with an alternate history of rock and roll in Salman Rushdie’s novel The Ground Beneath Her Feet.

In Richard Powers’ novel Orfeo, Peter Els is nicknamed “Bioterrorist [this composer]” after trying to encode melodies into bacteria. Powers also alluded to this composer in 1991’s The Gold Bug Variations.

Dino Buzzati used this form for a version of the Orpheus myth set in 1960s Milan. The protagonist listens to punk rock in rebellion against the extremism of the Islamic Revolution in a work in this form by Marjane Satrapi (“mar-ZHAHN sah-trah-pee”).

answers: galaxies [or galaxy; accept spiral galaxies]
Zone of Avoidance [prompt on Zone of Few Nebulae]
cosmic dust [or interstellar dust; or space dust; or stardust; prompt on interstellar medium or ISM] <WA, Astronomy>
parts: Name these astronomical objects whose “spiral” examples can be classified on a Hubble tuning fork diagram.

This region of the sky was originally labeled as one of “few Nebulae” by Richard Proctor. Almost no galaxies outside our own can be seen in this region, which corresponds to roughly 10 degrees on either side of the Milky Way’s galactic plane.

The concentration of this material in the Milky Way’s center is a major contributor to the Zone of Avoidance. Interstellar reddening is primarily caused by scattering off this material in the interstellar medium.

answers: unicorns [accept Young Woman with Unicorn or The Lady and the Unicorn]
Leonardo da Vinci [or Leonardo da Vinci]
Metropolitan Museum of Art [or The Met] <RK, Painting/Sculpture>
parts: Name these animals. A set of six tapestries whose entries represent the five senses, as well as a final entry featuring the phrase À mon seul désir (“ah mon suhl day-ZEER”), depict one of these animals alongside a lady of nobility.

The three-quarters profile and background landscape of Raphael’s Young Woman With Unicorn was allegedly inspired by one of this artist’s portraits. He painted Cecilia Gallerani holding an ermine (“ER-min”).
This New York museum’s “Cloisters” are home to the Hunt of the Unicorn tapestries. This largest art museum in the US also owns Raphael’s Colonna Altarpiece.

answers: Bön [or Bönpo]
Tibet [or Xīzàng]
bodhisattvas [prompt on Buddhas or enlightened ones] <JM, Religion>
parts: Name this religion whose scriptures were revealed to visionaries called tertöns. Buddhists assert that one of this religion’s gods, Tangla (“tahng-lah”), was converted by Padmasambhava (“pud-muh-SUM-buh-vuh”) to a local variant of Vajrayana Buddhism.
Bön was more widely practiced in this region before the introduction of its variety of Buddhism, which is led by the Dalai Lama.

The name of Tonpa Shenrab is speculated to be a translation of the term for these figures into the Zhang-Zhung (“zhahng-zhoong”) language. These compassionate beings include Avalokitesvara (“uh-VAH-loh-kee-TESH-vuh-ruh”).

answers: The Birthday Party
Harold Pinter
comedy of menace [or comedies of menace] <AR, Drama>
parts: Name this play set in a seaside boarding house that centers on the pianist Stanley Webber, who is taken away by Goldberg and McCann at the play’s end.
The Birthday Party was written by this British playwright, who depicted the bickering hitmen Ben and Gus in The Dumb Waiter.
Irving Wardle’s review of The Birthday Party in Encore magazine led him to coin this three-word phrase to characterize the contrasting humor and danger central to Pinter’s plays.

answers: The Bahamas [accept British Bahamas]
Blackbeard [or Edward Teach; or Edward Thatch]
Alexander Selkirk <ML, Commonwealth/Misc>
parts: Name this colony where Harry Oakes was murdered. This colony, ruled by Edward VIII after his abdication, freed dozens of rebels on an American slave ship who had landed on its Great Abaco Island in the Creole case.
This pirate made his home in the Bahamas just before England enforced colonization in the Bahamas. This pirate captained the Queen Anne’s Revenge.

The first Royal Governor of the Bahamas, Woodes Rogers, was better known for rescuing this Scottish sailor who was marooned in Chile’s Juan Fernández Archipelago, thus becoming the inspiration for Robinson Crusoe.

answers: Vincent van Gogh [prompt on Vincent]
Kirk Douglas
Akira Kurosawa (The other film is Ran.) <RK, Other Arts: Film>
parts: Name this artist. The oil-painted animated film Loving [this person] depicts this Dutch artist’s relationship with his brother Theo and includes shots of paintings like The Night Café.

This actor starred in Vincente Minnelli’s adaptation of an Irving Stone novel about Vincent van Gogh, Lust for Life. He later collaborated with Stanley Kubrick on the films Spartacus and Paths of Glory.

An aspiring artist enters into a landscape of the Langlois (“long-lwah”) Bridge and meets Vincent van Gogh in “Crows,” a short film from this director’s collection Dreams. A blood-orange sky provides the backdrop of the final shot of another of his films, which shows a blind man standing atop some ruins.

answers: Sahara Desert [accept Trans-Saharan trade]
Ghana Empire [or Wagadu]
razzias [or ghazwas or ghaziyas or ghazis] <WA, World History>
parts: Name this desert across which many slaves were brought by Arab traders. Those traders also conducted a gold–salt trade through this desert in such towns as Aoudaghost.

North African states also acquired many slave soldiers by importing from this African empire, which lost Aoudaghost to the Almoravids in the mid-11th century. Its capital was Koumbi Saleh (“KOOM-bee SAH-leh”).

This term, borrowed from Arabic, denotes raids that were conducted to enslave and plunder people, particularly by Moors in the Sahara and Barbary pirates along the coast. You may also give the Arabic word describing the soldiers who conducted those raids and other religious wars.

answers: roses [prompt on flowers]
lost generation [accept “You are all a lost generation”; prompt on lost]
“there there” [or “There is no there there.”; or There There] <RK, Misc Lit>
parts: Stein wrote “[This] is a [this] is a [this] is a [this]” in her poem “Sacred Emily.” Robert Burns compared his “Luve” to a “red, red” one of these flowers.

A garage owner allegedly inspired Stein to coin a phrase telling post-World War I Americans “You are all” this sort of group, a quote that Ernest Hemingway borrowed for the epigraph of The Sun Also Rises.

Upon returning to her home of Oakland, Stein remarked of its development that “There is no” this two-word phrase. Cheyenne and Arapaho author Tommy Orange borrowed this phrase for the title of a celebrated 2018 novel about a group of troubled Native Americans in Oakland.

answers: A. J. Ayer [or Alfred Jules Ayer; or “Freddie” Ayer]
positivism [or positivist approach; accept logical positivism]
David Hume <ML, Phil/Thought>
parts: Name this British philosopher who introduced the concept of the “verification principle” from the Vienna Circle to Anglophone philosophy. He wrote The Problem of Knowledge.

The positions of the Vienna Circle that Ayer introduced are called the “logical” variety of this empirical approach, which rejects metaphysics and instead grounds knowledge in verifiable reality. Auguste Comte promoted this approach in sociology.
Much earlier, this Scottish philosopher also promoted an empirical approach to knowledge in such books as An Enquiry Concerning Human Understanding.

answers: Ixion
centaurs [or kentauroi]
a fiery wheel [or a wheel of fire or similar answers; prompt on wheel or chariot wheel] <AR, Myths/Legends>
parts: Name this mythological husband of Dia who committed the first murder of a family member when he killed his father-in-law by pushing him onto burning coals.

Ixion thought he was having sex with Hera, but he was actually having sex with a cloud imitating her. That act created this race of drunken half-horse, half-men who fought Ixion’s kinfolk, the Lapiths.
For his crimes, Hermes bound Ixion to one of these specific objects.

answers: desmosomes [or macula adherens; do not accept or prompt on “adherens junction”]
calcium ion [or calcium 2+; or Ca2+]
anticonvulsants [or antiepileptics; or AEDs; accept drugs or medication for treating seizures or epilepsy] <RN, Biology: Genetics/Cell>
parts: Name these structures that are used for cell-to-cell adhesion. Cadherins are found on the extracellular portions of these junctions, while their intracellular portions are anchored to keratin.
Cadherin dimerization is dependent on this cation, which is also stored in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of muscle cells. Vitamin D promotes deposition of this ion in bones.

Stevens–Johnson syndrome, which destroys skin and mucous membranes, is often triggered by this class of drugs, which includes carbamazepine (“CAR-buh-MAZZ-uh-peen”), valproate (“val-PRO-ate”), and phenytoin (“fen-uh-TOH-in”).

answers: race [accept black people or African-American people or white people or Caucasian people; accept skin color; prompt on color]
Clark [accept Kenneth Clark or Maimie Clark]
stereotypes [accept stereotype threat] <RK, Social Science: Psych>
parts: Identify this characteristic. An “association test” created at Harvard measures the response time of participants pairing negative and positive words with people who differ in this characteristic.
In an experiment cited in the Brown v. Board decision, two psychologists with this surname found that all races of children did not prefer dolls that resembled African-Americans.

In an experiment examining a type of “threat” named for this concept, black students performed worse on a GRE after being reminded that it was an intelligence test. This term refers to generalizations about broad groups.

answers: funeral march [or marcia funebre; prompt on march]
Gustav Mahler
Edward Elgar [or Sir Edward William Elgar] <RK, Classical/Opera>
parts: Give this genre. A symphonic movement in this genre “in the manner of Callot (“ka-LO”)” features a minor-key rendition of “Frère Jacques” (“FRAIR-uh ZHOCK-uh”) introduced by the double bass, which is contrasted with the music of a Jewish klezmer band.
This Austrian composer included that funeral march in his First Symphony, which was named for Jean Paul’s novel Titan. He also composed the “Symphony of a Thousand.”

This composer’s second and final symphony, in E-flat major, includes a Larghetto funeral march in C minor. His wife Alice and his friend Augustus Jaeger are portrayed in movements titled “C.A.E.” and “Nimrod.”

answers: Queen Elizabeth I [prompt on Elizabeth]
Anne [accept Anne Boleyn; or Anne Bradstreet]
Valentine’s Day [or Saint Valentine’s Day] <RK, Poetry>
parts: During his first stint in the Tower, Walter Raleigh wrote “The Ocean’s Love to Cynthia,” who represented this person. This queen is allegorized as Gloriana in a poem that Raleigh sponsored, Edmund Spenser’s The Faerie Queene.

An author with this first name wrote a poem beginning “O death! rock me asleep” while awaiting execution in the Tower. A later poet with this first name wrote a poem addressing the “ill-formed offspring of my feeble brain.”

While in the Tower of London, Charles, Duke of Orléans, is credited with writing the first poem celebrating this day. Some birds meet on this day in Geoffrey Chaucer’s The Parlement of Foules (“fowls”), which helped establish its modern connotation.

answers: millet (“MILL-it”)
Nigeria
marriage [accept nuptials or nuptiality or wedlock; prompt on fertility or child-rearing] <WA, Geography>
parts: Thomas Talhelm found that a “Huai–Qin line” divides China into the rice-dominated, collectivist south and the individualistic north, whose primary crops are wheat and this hardy grain that can grow in low rainfall.

This country’s Middle Belt divides its Muslim north from its Christian south and has seen violence between Christian Berom farmers and Muslim Fulani pastoralists. The Middle Belt also contains its capital of Abuja.

In 1965, John Hajnal (“HYE-nall”) drew his namesake line from St. Petersburg to Trieste, splitting Europe into two regions characterized by different social patterns and customs with regard to this practice.

answers: anti-Markovnikov addition [do not accept or prompt on “Markovnikov”]
boron [prompt on B]
copper [prompt on Cu] <RN, Chemistry>
parts: Name this type of addition reaction that adds a molecule to the less-substituted carbon in a double or triple bond.

The classic anti-Markovnikov reaction involves adding a sterically-hindered group with a central atom of this element. This element, whose atomic number is 5, is often electron-deficient in compounds.
The azide–alkyne click reaction is catalyzed by this metal, whose sulfate forms bright blue crystals and was once known as blue vitriol.
